title: Final Reminder: deadline approaching for poster submissions to DCM2026
content:
Final reminder to submit a poster for the Dataverse Community Meeting 2026, 12-15 May, World Trade Center, Barcelona. The deadline is February 16, 2026 (note that the deadline for presentations has passed): https://dcm2026.com/call-for-papers/

Posters could cover one of the conference themes, a dataset, collection, or Dataverse repository you want to showcase, or tools and projects that integrate with Dataverse.

Take advantage of the Early Bird registration fee, with the deadline approaching, February 28:

title: Towards a data strategy for the Fifth International Polar Year (IPY5)
content: Planning of the IPY5 (2032-33) is underway and CODATA is excited to be a member of the IPY Planning Group. CODATA has a keen interest in ensuring that IPY5 is a success and marks another step forward in data stewardship. To that end, an IPY5 Data Task Group to develop an initial data strategy for data to be FAIR, handled with CARE, and preserved with TRUST has been proposed. title: Disaster Risk Reduction and Open Data Newsletter: January 2026 Edition
content:
The pulse of the planet

The explosion of data offers new ways to understand the economy—and change what gets measured, not just how.

Digital technologies are redefining how we see and manage the global economy. As Kenneth Cukier writes in Finance & Development, the earth is developing a “digital nervous system” through satellites, sensors, and AI that measure everything from deforestation and traffic to crop yields and emissions. content:

title: Read Now – Disaster Risk Reduction and Open Data Newsletter: November and December 2025 Edition
content:
Glaciers to Farms (G2F) Regional Program: Advancing Climate Resilience & Sustainable Development in Central and West Asia

Glacier systems in the Pamir and Tien Shan ranges are retreating rapidly; projections indicate over 50 per cent of glacier volume could be lost by 2100. This cryosphere meltdown is disrupting water cycles, threatening the livelihoods and food security of over 340 million people across nine countries. Without urgent intervention, communities risk worsening poverty, displacement, and instability.

title: Bridging Two Worlds: Reflections from the IDW2025 Panel on Research Data and Data Science
content:
At IDW2025, a group of speakers from around the globe gathered to address a long-standing problem: although data is the common currency of both research data management and data science, the two communities often work in parallel worlds—each with its own conferences, training pipelines, infrastructures, and priorities. As Christine Kirkpatrick noted in her opening remarks, this separation persists despite converging challenges around stewardship, reproducibility, education, and ethics. She framed the session as an invitation to rethink how these domains might come together.
